The biggest red flag here is that Chipotle only saw same-store sales growth of 0.9% during the quarter, which is a far cry from the double-digit comps growth it experienced prior to its food safety issues.
What does this mean?

Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc. (NYSE: CMG) announced today that it has reached a resolution with the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Central District of California related to the 2015-2018 norovirus outbreak incidents at several of its restaurants in California, Ohio, and Virginia.

The price increase is an effort to offset rising labor and food costs which could put pressure on profit margins.
The issue here is that if the competition doesn't follow suit with similar price increases, Chipotle may lose market share to other fast casual dining options.
Meanwhile, same-store sales growth has been sluggish as the brand struggles to recover from past food safety issues and increased competition in the fast-casual space.
With same-store sales growth already slowing down, it may not be enough to spark a turnaround for the stock.
Furthermore, some customers might not take kindly to the increased prices, which could negatively impact sales volume.

And there's more...
Chipotle has faced numerous challenges lately, including increased competition, changing consumer preferences, and supply chain issues.
If the increase is not well-received by customers, it could negatively impact sales and ultimately profits.
The company has been dealing with higher costs associated with implementing new policies aimed at improving customer satisfaction and loyalty.
This comes at a time when comparable sales are also under pressure from increased competition and changing consumer habits (less frequent dining out, more meal kit delivery services).
The company has been struggling with declining sales and same-store sales growth since last year’s norovirus outbreak at one of its locations.
Additionally, there are concerns about the impact of minimum wage hikes and potential unionization efforts on their labor costs.
While Chipotle has made efforts to improve food safety and recover from the crisis, it still faces challenges in regaining customer trust.
They have also faced negative publicity around the handling of employee benefits and compensation.
The increased prices might not necessarily result in higher revenue if customers are deterred by the new pricing structure.
The brand was already facing intense competition in the fast-casual space and now has to deal with increasing costs.
In order to regain customer trust and confidence, they need to invest in marketing efforts, new menu items, and increased digital capabilities.
In addition, competition from other fast-casual chains and changing consumer preferences have added to the challenges faced by Chipotle.

Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc.’s (CMG) stock fell as much as 4.5% after reporting Q2 earnings that missed estimates, despite the price hike announcement.
Furthermore, increasing menu prices can lead to further declines in sales volume if customers become more price-sensitive.
While a 3-4% price increase might not seem like much, it can add up quickly, especially if customers are already feeling the pinch from other restaurants raising their prices as well.
In the meantime, the company is trying to balance the need to invest in the business with the need to maintain profitability.
Furthermore, while a 4% to 5% price hike might not seem like much, it’s still a bold move considering the highly competitive fast-casual dining landscape.
While Chipotle has made progress in recovering from the crisis, it still faces intense competition in the fast casual space, particularly from other burrito and Mexican-inspired chains.
Raising prices might help boost revenue, but it also risks alienating customers who may not be willing or able to pay more for their burritos and bowls.
Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc (CMG) shares are down over 25% in the past year as a result, making it one of the worst performers in the restaurant industry.
CMG was downgraded by several analysts in recent weeks as it struggles to recover from the setbacks.

Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. (CMG) Q1 2017 earnings call highlighted the ongoing struggles:
CEO Brian Niccol: “We know we still have work to do to fully recover from our challenges in 2016, but I'm pleased with the progress we're making.”
CFO John Hartung: “Food costs as a percentage of revenue increased by 150 basis points due to higher avocado prices, waste, and promotional expenses.”
Same-store sales decline: -4.8% vs. -3.2% consensus estimate.
While investors may welcome the news of a price hike as a way to boost revenue, it also risks further alienating customers who are already turned off by negative perceptions of the brand.
It remains to be seen whether customers will stomach the higher prices or if it’ll lead to even more sluggish sales.
It’s not all bad news though.
While I think it’s wise for Chipotle to take steps to maintain profitability, I worry that customers might not be willing to absorb higher prices.
The good news is that Chipotle still maintains a strong brand reputation, albeit somewhat tarnished, and loyal customers who are willing to pay a premium for their menu items.
Furthermore, the higher prices may not necessarily translate into higher profits as customers may become more price-sensitive and demand decreases.
Additionally, the company has been dealing with higher labor costs due to minimum wage increases in various states and cities.
While increasing prices may help mitigate some of these costs, it remains to be seen whether customers will tolerate higher prices without negatively impacting sales.
While the 4% price hike may help mitigate some cost pressures, it remains to be seen whether customers will continue to accept higher prices in a competitive fast-casual space.
I believe there are too many unknowns surrounding the sales momentum of this quarter and potential margin pressures that may arise from higher labor and food costs.
With the recent decline in restaurant industry sentiment, I remain cautious on Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) until we get more clarity on these issues.
Furthermore, it’s unclear if consumers will respond positively to menu price increases amidst a highly competitive fast-casual landscape.
I will stay cautious on this stock until we get more clarity around these issues.
Furthermore, I’m not convinced that a price increase will lead to significant revenue growth if it comes at the expense of lost customers due to reduced affordability.
Additionally, the competitive landscape in fast casual remains fierce.
Until I see consistent evidence of improving sales trends and stronger profitability, I prefer to remain sidelined on the stock.

Investors should note that Chipotle faces stiff competition in the fast-casual space, particularly from players like Panera Bread (PNRA) and Sweetgreen, which have made significant investments in digital ordering and delivery capabilities.
For now, it’s better to hold off and reassess after we get more clarity on the quarterly performance.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) closed yesterday at $445.95 per share, down $11.65 (-2.55%) on 1.43 million shares traded hands.
